meanings.definition: To throw or drop something from a moving vehicle or ship
meanings.sent1: The sailor had to jettison the heavy cargo to lighten the ship.
meanings.sent2: The astronaut had to jettison the old fuel tank to continue the space mission.
meanings.sent3: The pirate decided to jettison the treasure chest overboard to fool the pursuing ships.
meanings.sent4: In order to survive, the hiker had to jettison his heavy backpack like excess baggage.
meanings.sent5: The delivery truck driver had to jettison the damaged goods to prevent further accidents.

meanings.definition: To discard or get rid of something no longer needed or wanted
meanings.sent1: The company had to jettison the outdated equipment to make room for new technology.
meanings.sent2: She decided to jettison her old clothes to create space in the closet.
meanings.sent3: The chef had to jettison the spoiled ingredients to avoid a kitchen disaster.
meanings.sent4: After the renovation, they had to jettison the old furniture to give the room a fresh look.
meanings.sent5: To declutter the house, they had to jettison unnecessary items accumulated over the years.
